title: AB 332
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature finds that Californians are concerned about the costs of growing older, with two-thirds worried about affording long-term care. Sixty-three percent are as concerned about paying for long-term care as they are for future health care. A majority of respondents in California cannot afford more than three months of nursing home care at $6,000 per month. About 40% cannot afford a single month of care. Concerns about paying for long-term care are prevalent among all income levels and partisan affiliations, with 88% of Latino voters lacking long-term care insurance. The Legislature aims to establish a task force to explore creating a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will be created in the Department of Insurance to design and implement this program under the leadership of the commissioner. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members, including the commissioner as chair, representatives from various departments, appointees by the Governor and Speaker of the Assembly. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force includes members appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly and the Senate Committee on Rules, with no compensation allowed. The Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act applies to task force meetings, and their responsibilities are outlined. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is tasked with exploring the design and implementation of a statewide long-term care insurance program to provide options for individuals seeking coverage for costs related to disability and long-term care services. This includes examining eligibility, benefits, financing, and coordination with Medi-Cal and other public resources. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is exploring the inclusion of a long-term care insurance program in the state disability insurance structure, potentially funded through a payroll tax increase. It may allow working adults to enroll voluntarily with premium contributions, and could have a mandatory enrollment with an opt-out option. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program that includes a basic insurance benefit for working adults with cognitive limitations. It aims to help individuals stay in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services and offsetting costs for those with chronic conditions. The program may have a mandatory enrollment with an opt-out option. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program to help adults with chronic conditions by offsetting costs and providing basic insurance benefits. The program aims to coordinate benefits with existing private health care coverage and address the demands on the long-term care workforce in California. It also considers establishing a joint public and private system to make long-term care accessible to more individuals in the state. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force in California is considering establishing a joint public and private system to make long-term care accessible to more individuals. Recommendations will be made regarding regulatory provisions for accessing existing and future long-term care insurance programs. The department and governmental agencies involved will operate within their existing budgetary resources for implementation. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force in California will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program in a report to be submitted by July 1, 2017 to the commissioner, Governor, and Legislature. The report will comply with Section 9795 of the Government Code. To ensure a viable long-term care insurance program, an actuarial report of task force recommendations must be produced by July 1, 2018, and approved by task force members before submission to the Legislature. The commissioner has the authority to seek private funds for program implementation. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2019, unless extended or deleted by a later statute enacted before that date.
